												Of the Sands of Time trilogy, Warrior Within is easily the most controversial of the bunch. Forgoing the whimsical Nights of Arabia theme of the much beloved Sands of Time, Warrior Within employs a much darker tone, replacing melodic instrumentals with blood pumping metal music, and an emperor’s majestic castle with that of some dreadful thing from a metal album cover. Gone, too, is the storybook hero known only as the Prince, who is now a curse spewing, murder loving psychopath, easy to anger and eager to slice open stomachs. Understandably, not all took a liking to the new Prince of Persia, and many either wrote it off or gave up after dying in the first 10 minutes, all while cursing the monsters at Ubisoft who would dare slight their beloved franchise so vehemently. I am ashamed to admit that while I did not join in the publisher bashing those many years prior, I did assume the many fans’ angers as legitimate. After having neglected the franchise for many years since the original, I have finally played through the trilogy’s entirety. Lo and behold, my judgment is thus: Warrior Within is the best of the Prince of Persia trilogy, and one of the most challenging and equally frustrating and rewarding titles I have ever had the pleasure of besting.Where its predecessor, The Sands of Time, relied on linear level progression, a typically gradually increasing difficulty, and relatively basic (and easy) combat, Warrior Within features a (sort of) open world, varied weapons of combat, and enemies that will break your face if you’re not perfect. It also features a higher emphasis on combat than its predecessor, and some of the most frustrating puzzle and enemy design than any other game I’ve played in years. But understand what I mean by that. Warrior Within, for the entire duration, never held my hand. The moment I felt I had a handle on how to deal with an enemy type, a brand new exploding, near unavoidable dog animal thing would be introduced. Obviously, it wasn’t always an exploding dog thing, but you get the point. WW is never easy or gradual in its difficulty. It’s not typically fair, either, but it also never felt impossible, and that’s what made it fantastic. For comparison, while playing Demon’s Souls, I always felt in control of what I was doing, and typically only died if I was quick to run into a room before checking for barriers to hide behind, traps or tricky enemies in the shadows. WW will put you in a room and deal death unto you until you learn to deal with it, and the experience became infinitely rewarding upon besting said situations. Puzzles don’t quite follow the same degree of difficulty that the combat does, but the challenge comes in unintended traversal. By puzzles, I refer to the Prince of Persia’s method of travel; running along walls, sliding down ropes and hanging banners, and avoiding the many, many spikes and saw blades inexplicably sticking out of walls. The open world aspect of Warrior Within allows you to re-visit any portion of the island that you’ve previously visited, and you don’t necessarily have to follow the same paths. However, the design of these pathways are sometimes altered by the game’s events, and even when they aren’t, traversal in any way different from the standard is a challenge in and of itself, as the developers clearly did not design these paths to be easily followed backwards (or forwards, for that matter), as you will have to do. Worse yet, enemy spawns remain, especially those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ dogs I mentioned previously, the ones that can take half of your health. If this sounds frustrating to you, it should. But by the point you should even be considering doing anything like this, you will have already become invested in beating down this seemingly personal hell that the developers have created just for you.I won’t divulge any of my secrets for passing through Warrior Within, and quite frankly, I would recommend any and all to refrain from guides as much as possible throughout (except for the collectibles, you’ll need a guide for those). Warrior Within is a truly brutal and often unfair achievement in sadistic game design. It’s also one of my most satisfying completions in the entirety of my gaming career. Nearly every instance of combat in this title will chew on your face and kick you in your ♥♥♥ until you really learn to play it. The learning curve can be steep and unfair, and you will want to quit. Don’t. There are no tricks to Warrior Within, and only your skill, and hopefully a share of dumb luck, will see you succeed. What faults it has, of which there are plenty, only add to the experience.

												The second part of the amazing Prince of Persia trilogy. This time it's a whole lot different kind of adventure. No more fancy palace and no more romance in the air. This game tells you a different story. Prince of Persia: Warrior Within is an excellent game that reveals its greatness as you progress. It starts off a bit run of mill with our moody hero slicing up bad guys, but things take a turn for the best when you get to the island. From here on it's a mind bending challenge after mind bending challenge - each more well thought out and engrossing than the last.The graphics are very dark and atmospheric and the gameplay is great too. The Prince feels nice to control as he runs across walls, swings on poles and does tons of cool acrobatic tricks.They made some huge changes to the fighting system. Now there are lots of combos and even enviormental kills. Now you can grab and throw enemies off ledges and over them.The voice acting seems worse to me.  Especially because Yuri Lowenthal's voice is gone. The music is very different from the first game. This time it's all rock and metal, which I didn't really like. Because I'm not a fan of such. But it was necessary. The game forces you to run away from an dark, terrifying guardian of time named Dahaka. And the music is chosen well for this part of the game. The game looks and feels awesome. The plot is a sick sticky web that makes you think fast and act faster. New powers and weapons are always nice to see in a game. And trust me, there are a lot of weapons here. Especially because the Prince can now Dual Wield. Lots of secret areas, just like the first game. And some awesome hidden weapons too. You'll have to stray off course in order to find them. Prince of Persia: Warrior Within is a challenging and fun game. It requires brawn, brains and an appreciation of wicked looking island. It doesn't beat the first game, but still...10/10

However, If good combat and thrilling visuals sells it to you, then Warrior Within is certainly worth a look.

												You know, this game is kind of the black sheep of the franchise (a franchise that might I add, has been ignored stupidly when it's one of the best Ubisoft has). If you ask fans about it they'll either tell you they love it or they hate it, there doesn't seem to be a middle ground. However I do find it a great game, and as I usually do with my reviews, I'm gonna start with the negative aspects of the game first.First and foremost, the biggest problem this game has are the glitches and bugs. It's no secret that Ubisoft ♥♥♥♥s up their newer releases but their old games are no strangers to that as well. This game still has quite the number of graphic bugs, collision detection, glitched physics and other crap you might think of. And sure, some are useful like the wall-running glitch that can let you extend your wall-running distance effortlessly, but others are a pain in the ♥♥♥ that will cause a game over on you, such as going through the floor. It's quite shameful that Ubisoft hasn't and will never fix these mistakes, really. I will also add that the game has no Steam support what-so-ever.Second, this is something that you can see a lot on Ubisoft games, from both the new and old. If you pick the Hard difficulty, all that will change is the HP of enemies and how much damage they do to you. Come on, that's not difficulty, that's artificial difficulty. And it sucks. Honestly, ignore the Hard difficulty. I went through the game with it and it just makes the game worse, specially when bosses just have too much health and deal too much, while Easy difficulty is programmed for babies.Third is something that's not a problem with me, but with lots of fans: the setting itself. You see, Sands of Time had a lot of charm on it's style, it was told like a fairy tale and didn't really have much violence; it had a bigger focus on the puzzles and platforming than in combat. Warrior Within flips it over, there's barely any puzzles anymore, platforming has been reworked and it's still there, but combat got a gigantic overhaul and it's the bigger focus. It also went from a faily tale to a violent game in which the main character decapitates, cuts in half and utterly murders most of what's on his way in overly cool ways while the music goes from persian-like music to edgy hard-rock/metal. As I said, it's not really a problem for me, but I know for a fact that a lot of people disliked this game because of it, and you should be aware of it.Lastly, I can't help it but to think the two female characters in the game got stupidly sexualized for no reason what so ever. Specially Shadde of whatever her name is, literally the first time you see her, it's her gigantic ♥♥♥ taking most of the screen. What the ♥♥♥♥.However, looking away from those problems what we got left is a pretty solid platforming game that had some seriously fun combat mechanics, a decent story and catchy music.The map is pretty cool, and I've always been a fan of it. In the Sands of Time you always went forward and would most likely never visit most of those places again; that ain't happening here, as the Island of Time and it's gigantic damn fortress is well connected and you'll be going from one place to the other. It's sort of like an open world with it's own mini-hub area connecting them all, which I like, andit doubles as good for having both present and past versions of almost all areas, which is really cool when you finally do notice which ones are the same on different times. Though I must question what kind of sense do all of those places make in an in-game prespective, it's impossible to go from one side to the other unless you're some sort of acrobatic monster like the Prince.I've always liked the story of this game, it's not too deep to get lost on it but it does entertain during the 7-10 hours it takes to go through it. It also likes to make you question what's going on early and give you hints of what happened, and incase you didn't catch it, answer them later near the end. And having two different endings is also cool, the other games also needed something like that.The combat is absolutely ♥♥♥♥ing Badass. Tons of combos, plenty of weapons, a cluster♥♥♥♥ of ways to deal with an enemy, and it's also quite ♥♥♥♥ing violent and fun to watch. It's certainly a gigantic step-up from The Sands of Time, and I wish Ubisoft didn't just copy it on the sequel (which had almost all the same moves but the gameplay was more stealth focused, which just didn't feel right).The music, while edgy as hell and really different from the previous game, feels quite fitting in here. The atmosphere is really dark and gritty, having hard-rock/metal for half the soundtrack does wonders. Do I recommend this game? Certainly. However be aware of two things: First, the price. Ubisoft usually sucks at pricing and a game this old is kinda expensive at it's current price. On a big sale though, it's a great purchase. Second, that you should totally play The Sands of Time first if you haven't yet. Otherwise you won't understand ♥♥♥♥.TL;DR Edition: Great mix between platforming and action-based gameplay with plenty of violence and metal to go along with it. Sure it's edgy as all ♥♥♥♥ but it's also really fun. Story is decent and catchy, the map got a lot of detail, only big negative points being the God-damn bugs.

												Having played all prince of Persia games, I think this is one of the better ones, but not the best. And the reason why it isn't is because of how the saving works. A mechanic that is so badly done it destroys the enjoyment of this game.Despite its age the graphics hold up. Not because of the latest state of the art graphics obviously, but because it fits the game and there is nothing detracting from it. The art style is also superb with interesting locations and beautiful vistas. The only gripe is that there is only a 4:3 ratio and not 16:9. I believe you can mod it, but I think the game breaks slightly if you do. The story is nothing to write home about and often feels very cheesy and videogame-cringeworthy. You know, bad lines and scantily clad women with enormous boobs. It just feels way to forced and out of place.If you are familiar with the game -series, you'll find great platforming and puzzles in this one as well. This is probably the most challenging game in the whole series. Puzzles are truly difficult at times, and you don't always know where to go. You do have a map, but it is not particularly helpful. I found myself going down the wrong path quite a few times because It is not obvious where you are going next, especially if you have not played the game for a while.The combat is the best in the series. Lots of variety, "different weapons", many combos, tight controls and fun game-play. You can even use the environment a bit. It works great with mouse and keyboard, but I also found that a controller (a little fiddling to get it working properly) worked quite well.This is all good. But what eventually makes this game the only one I have never completed(!), is how the saving works, and what happes when you die. You can only save at certain locations and there is no autosave. So what? That is normal of older games. Well, it takes quite a while to save (first he drinks for quite a while, then you go in to a menu asking if you want to save, then you get asked where to save, and then ok etc - a lot of small steps to save that feels really tedious after a while). Also, these save locations are sparse, especially later in the game. Which means that you might have to go through a bunch of difficult puzzles, beat monsters, and oops 15 minutes later you died and guess what, you have to redo all that again. If you find the boss and/or monsters hard you have to redo that quite a few times. The problem is that you have to redo all of it, not just the part you find difficult.This is absolutely hair-pullingly frustrating. It is not fun to replay 10-15 minutes of platform puzzles (that sometimes are quite difficult) and then you die to the next section of monsters or bosses. Sometimes the game seems to aknowledge this problem and you don't always start over at your last savepoint, but at a specific points in the game. But this doesn't happen often enough. This really feels unfair when the camera and/or controls can be the fault of your death or you might not know where to go. And the whole "you died" screen animation... It seems silly to bring up, but the whole experience from pressing the wrong button, or perhaps not seeing what is going on because of bad camera angles, then dying in slowmotion, getting the "you died screen" that is just a tad too long and you can't skip it, then going back to load your game and realizing you just lost a bunch of progress... - it all ads up, and takes too long to be fun.It is a shame because it really is a good game otherwise, and could have been one of the better ones. But now I would say it is the 3rd or 4th in the series because of this problem, because your overall experience is more frustrating than fun. Otherwise it has it all, great combat, nice platforming, bosses, good puzzles and a great theme and art style.Also, the music is not the best. They were going for some kind of tough rock-style. While I don't mind that kind of music, it just doesn't fit as well in this game and also feels rather repetitive.I still reckommend this game, but only for the die-hard fans who enjoys a little torture and no hand-holding.

												Warrior Within is a worthy sequel to the great Sands of Time. The story continues seven years after the events in the Sands of Time with the Prince of Persia as he sets out to find the Empress who created the sands... of time. His goal is to stop her and change his fate. In the first game, after stabbing the hourglass with the Dagger of Time, the Prince had released the Sands and changed the timeline. That is why the Prince embarks to the Island of Time to confront the Empress, to change his fate permanently.One of the more notable aspects of Warrior Within is how violent it is. The tone is much dark than it's predecessor and even the levels are grimier. But the platforming, bar hopping, ledge jumping, wall running, etc; it's all still there. And still just as fun. But what's even more notable about this game is the element of time travel. The plot gets really interesting about 3/4ths of the way through when various mysteries are uncovered and pieces are put together by the prince. His development and keen insight were a joy to watch throughout.One last thing, make sure you get all nine life upgrades to get the water sword for the alternate ending, which in reality is the canonical ending that continues into The Two Thrones. Plus it's so much more rewarding than the regular ending.Anyway, great game, but my only major complaint might be the drastic changes in music, from the Middle-eastern styled orchestral to the guitar driven metal. 												 I must start by saying Warrior Within is my least favorite of the trilogy. I played the entire series back in the day and recently purchased them again while they were on sale. The gameplay is alright, the game itself can be enjoyable but the plot isn't really that great compaired to the other games.   The major problem with the plot is that if you jump from the first game Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time to this you won't really know what's going on, from my understanding this game continues off of a side game created for the ds. That's a pretty bad idea in my oppinion, but after a short while you understand what's going on but will most likely wish there was some more detail on what happened inbetween the two games. But I do give the game a little bit of props for having a little replayability by having an alternative ending. The alternative ending is what leads to the beginning of The Two Thrones so I do reccomend getting all the life upgrades. The game suffers through a few annoyences, for example throughout the playthrough you will probably notice that they try and make the game seem badass in every aspect. Another example: Changing direction on a swing pole is left to chance it seems as the Prince sometimes turns and sometimes not. Gladly there are almost no time sensitive jumps in this fashion. You also still need to hold down the action button for all those things to work. Another example: Holding down the direction button to move the Prince forwards does not always result in him going forward, because the game takes the bloody camera angle into account, so instead of just pushing forward on the stick to move a rotating lever, you have to also rotate your stick to move it...*sigh*And my main gripe with the game: The god damn back tracking. I needed 15 hours on easy with a guide to complete this one, I visited some areas 3 or 4 times due to story reasons. You'd better memorize all the areas (in the past and present zones nonetheless) or use a guide. I shudder taking a break for a week or a month from this, coming back and realizing that I have no clue whatsoever where to go and how to get there. The game is an enigma. While it does have a "map", it's absolutely useless, as it's just an "overworld map" and offers NO details whatsoever. Infuriating.Another gripe: The last portion of the game is, again, just back tracking and repetition, but also extremely trivial. There is almost no way to fail at that stage and combat becomes extremely simplistic.What does it do well then? Well, it's still fun swinging around, the story is interesting and the past/present mechanic is pretty neat. However, the game needed to be streamlined. game, a lot of people got very upset with the developers for two reasons:A) They expected the game to carry with the same "tone" from the first game, this game in exchange it's dark, gritty, obscure, really explain where you need to go.Which really takes me up to the next problem that I have.The freaking pc port of this game is a mess, the game lacks basic graphic options, something understandable because of the games age, but tedious nonetheless, the game doesn't open up when clicking on "play" inside Steam, instead it throws a screen showing my system specs (24gb ram, gtx 970, i5 6600k), that obviously surpass the system requirements from the game, but since the game doesn't recognize this specs, it simply doesn't allow me to launch my game.In order to fix this I had to go to the main folder of the game, and launch the game directly from there, while simultaneously keeping the "launcher" with my system specs, running in the background.It's the only way I got to run the game.In order to then use my controller, increase the resolution to my screens native one, and skip the five minute cutscenes, I had to download patches, rebind keys, and delete some folders inside the game's directory. It was a process that took me around forthy minutes or so, but it was tedious and more importantly, it was relatively quick, because I knew where to look. (Thank you pcgamingwiki)After that...It's a fun game, the puzzles and the combat are great for the most part, climbind around and avoiding deathtraps it's enjoyable and fun, but then the game takes some design choices that in the name of "challenge" end up making the game extremely tedious to play, stuff like getting chased around by an enemy that you have to outrun, only getting the ability to "correct" your mistakes by using a limited supply of "sands of time" which allow you to go back to a specific position before you made whatever mistake got you killed in the first place, only to then having the limited supply of sands of time being the biggest problem of your playthrough, then some enemies that dodge each and every single one of your attacks, or block most of them, while they have attacks that "break" your defence...It just gets up to a point in which the game breaks it's own flow and ends up making the playing of it, tedious, and annoying, and eventually a section that would usually take you half an hour to complete, ends up taking you two, or three, and then it becomes tedious and annoying, and that frightening question that comes up in a game that clearly bothers you shows it's head.Is it worth it?And I don't think it is, the game might have been an incredible game before, and maybe if you can look past the terrible design choices that the game carries, and how horribly some of them have aged, with a terrible camera that switches in the most inconvinient moment making you fall to your death, then maybe you can find some enjoyment from beginning to end, but this is a game that hasn't aged well, I don't mean the graphics...Who cares about the graphics of a twelve year old game?But...It is a game that has design choices, and mechanics, that games have actively been trying to avoid, specifically because of how frustrating they can be.And I just don't like that, sorry...

The combat is so repetitive and unsatisfying that you'll look for every opportunity to skip it in order to continue with the platforming elements of the game. On hard mode at least, the enemies have way too much hp, and you can easily find yourself repeating the same attack patterns over and over literally a dozen or more times before the enemy finally falls. And god forbid you're trapped in a group of several enemies. For some reason most of your moves have next to no block recovery, which means you're taking damage one way or another. Even properly timed counter-attacks can result in the enemy still hitting you.Another major issue is the game is just way too hard for its own good. By midway through the game you're begging for every save point that comes your way. Not only does the game not feature a save-anywhere feature, its checkpoints are virtually nonexistent. This means sometimes you'll lose entire minutes of progress because of a platforming mistake.Speaking of platforming, it is actually quite good for the most part, very much up-to-par with what you get in the original Sands of Time. However, you'll often get lost and frustrated because of the game's terrible camera angles and misguided use of an open world design that has you backtracking through several areas.Probably the most aggravating thing about the game is that it's clearly rushed / unfinished. There's a lot of gameplay and graphical glitches that are surprisingly easy to trigger through normal gameplay. Even the way the prince lands on certain beams can provoke glitches where he temporarily appears to be landing on some different type of platform.Even little details about the game will tend to ♥♥♥♥ you off. For example, there are time travel portals you can activate. Each portal has 4 switches you have to press to activate them and the order is random. EVERY. SINGLE. TIME. It creates a meaningless guessing game each time and feels utterly pointless.Whereas the original game feels polished and has a certain charm, this one is just an incomplete mess. The wholy gritty, badass prince vibe they were going with this game falls flat on its face, and is borderline cringy at times.I can't believe I'm saying this, but even Forgotten Sands is a better game. 												Warning: the following review may contain spoilers.Warrior Within has quite a mixed opinion among fans of the Prince of Persia franchise. The negative arguments have some rational points such as the ridiculously skimpy outfits of the two major female characters and, at times, impossible to control camera angles. However there are many arguments made as "negatives" despite the fact that they are completely subjective.The dramatic shift in tone from Sands to WW can definitely be unappealing for those who enjoyed the more colorful and lighter aspects of Sands but this is based on opinion, rather than based on quality. The darker and more pale colored environments in WW are actually done quite well as they enforce a more negative attitude without being outright depressing or boring. This is the reaction that the player is supposed to experience, so saying that the dark environments are "bad" for not being lighter or more pretty seems illogical. There are also plenty of areas to explore, each with their own theme and personality (so to speak) i.e. the hanging gardens and mechanical tower, but always adhering to the theme of appearing pale and unwelcoming.Another misrepresented point of the game is backtracking - while Sands was a constant adventure that continually sent the prince through various areas and rarely revisiting the same location twice, WW features quite a bit of going back and forth through familiar locations. This is often cited as "lazy" level design or "lack of creativity" but misses the point that the level designers wanted the world to feel real. I admire the idea of constantly finding new areas to explore but half way through Sands I started to wonder if I was still in Azad or not, WW continues to send you to new places for the majority of the game but also tried to combine these newer areas from the later period of the story into the locations previously visited as it makes the game world feel connected. I must also point out the difference between time periods (past and present) as it allowed the level designers to create two distinct environments in the same location; the distopian present and the glorious past. An idea that I very much admire.Finally we come to one of the biggest issues of WW - the prince. Many fans hated the way his character had changed, going from a young, happy go lucky joker to a more grizzled, vulgar and take no prisoners soldier, stating that they come off as two completely different people. The problem with this argument is that in the game world it has been seven years since Sands. Anyone reading this can look back at their own lives from seven years ago and see differences between their behaviour before and now and they didn't have an invincible beast trying to kill them for all that time. If we also bear in mind the dilemma the prince faces in WW - NO hope, you WILL die, you CANNOT change your fate, it's all very negative and this all rubs off onto the character. He despises the fate he has been handed for a mistake he had no way of forseeing, he aggresively disregards the warnings of failure and is determined to free himself from this living nightmare. To be perfectly honest, the prince comes off as more of an anti-hero; a very selfish individual, willing to step over people he grows to care for (i.e. Kaileena) and takes no consideration of the consequence of his actions should he succeed in removing the Sands of Time from ever existing. It would be very easy to change the story so that the prince is a villain due to just how selfish his actions are, however, I personally like this anti-hero character. Rather than trying to "save the day" like a good generic hero always does, this hero is only interested in saving himself. It's a very interesting concept but, as mentioned before, can be very unappealing for fans who enjoyed the personality displayed in Sands.Moving over to the more positive elements, or at least the positives that haven't already been mentioned...Combat has been expanded from the previous game, allowing for the prince to make better use out of two weapons, or opting to use one weapon, as well as adding newer ways to interact with the surrounding areas and enemies during combat. The fighting system has lost it's smoother, more fluid movements from Sands but takes on a more aggressive and in-your-face approach, which is fitting for the mood of the game. I won't go too far into details but players willing to experiment and play around with the various attacks, counter-attacks, vaulting, running and jumping will have a lot of fun finding the various ways to slice their enemies in half or perform decapitations. Or at least I did.The story has some questionable points if you look closely enough, but, at it's heart, is coherent, consistent with its facts and, while some plot points are more than a little obvious, the overall journey is quite unpredictable and leaves the player questioning if the prince will actually succeed, that is until you realize that it makes for a pretty crappy ending if you ultimately fail your mission.Final Verdict: Warrior Within is a good game, fans of it's predecessor should at least consider trying it out but bear in mind that the two have very differnt personalities. If you don't like dark, gritty and violent then this is NOT the game for you. I personally enjoy this game a lot and because of its age it doesn't require a high spec computer to run (I'm using an HP laptop straight off the shelf and the game runs nice and smoothly)4 stars out of 5 from me. Great game but still does enough wrong to lose out on a flawless victory.

												Much like its predecessor, this game has aged remarkably well.  It started off rather slow, but once I became familiar with the combat system I found it hard to tear myself away from the computer.  The combat system is a major improvement over the original and places a great deal of freedom at your fingertips.  Moreover, it fosters a blend of action and exploration to keep you interested and to keep the game fast-paced.  When the game is at its best, you'll find yourself catapulting from acrobatic duels into high-adrenaline chase sequences through beautiful Gothic-style ruins.  I recommend it, especially for the price.There is one caveat worth mentioning.  This game is a significant departure from the original, especially with regard to its ambiance and storyline.  Warrior Within tries too hard to be dark and edgy, often to the point of ridiculousness.  That's a minor critique though, and if you can look past the stylistic flaws, I think you'll find that this game has aged gracefully and serves as a worthy successor to The Sands of Time.
